The first case, Weyerhaeuser Company v. United States Fish and Wildlife Service concerns the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's (FWS) designation of private land in Louisiana as critical habitat for the dusky gopher frog.
Under the Endangered Species Act, property owners of critical habitat are barred from most uses of the property. In this case, the FWS designation requires the property owners to uproot trees and replace them with different species; halt timber management activities; and allow the land to be populated with frogs.
The Fifth Circuit affirmed the district court's ruling that deferred to the FWS habitat designation.
The Supreme Court's decision could turn on the degree of deference afforded the FWS, and what constitutes agency discretion.

Boy, this is a tough one. Four votes (the conservatives) are determined.  So the probability of "Yes", as I see it, turns on two independent events: 1. The chance that Breyer or another liberal joins the conservatives
2. The chance of an 8-0 vacate compromise OR a 4-4 that is reargued later this same term. I would peg 1 at something like 25-30% based on oral argument, but 2 is very hard to estimate.  Last year the Court was very slow, so I think there is far more of a chance of a reargument next Term than most people are acknowledging here.  As that is a "no", I'll go with 85% on the whole.  But starting around December this one will start falling with every week that they don't come out with an opinion.

My prediction is not based on what I believe, but on what I think the Justices believe, by reading their line of questions in the oral argument. While the Court seems to be divided along the natural fault line, the questions and answers aren't easy to read, since there are many interruptions. But in the end, I believe the Court, will side with Weyerhaeuser, especially when later, Judge Kavanaugh will be confirmed and join the Court. I could even see Justice Breyer concur with the majority, but writing his own opinion. (EDIT: but perhaps he could use what the government lawyer suggested to him, that since the conservation is in line with current usage, the designation of "critical habitat" isn't outlandish. In that case, he will side with the liberal Justices). EDIT2: as for the 4/4 decision: if Judge Kavanaugh is confirmed, he will joint the Court and will be able to decide without having to sit at oral argument, unless the confirmation is delayed further and nobody will joint the court for the next two years).

I would like to encourage people to submit reasons for their view on this case.   My bias is conservative; I am anti-Chevron. 
I have an additional bias that I should like to save frogs.  I have read the entire transcripts on this case.   I am sorry - I think Weyerhauser is attempting to pull linguistic legerdemain.  They argue because frogs are not their now, it is not habitat.  Sorry.  Not so.   As argued on pages 52/53 -and several other places  - habitat can exist independently of whether or not creature populations have been destroyed.  Whooping cranes had a habitat that covered most of North America.  The shooting of millions of cranes for millinery didnt' make their native range habitat any less habitat.  Conversely, if you pave over a pond, and frogs still manage to hang on for a few generations - that doesn't make asphault their native habitat.  Now.  Is this an unconstitutional taking of land?  Yes, yes it probably is.    But I don't know that the case is ripe for that determination.   It isn't the issue being addressed.   If the appelant had appealed saying this was a governments taking case,  I would completely agree that this will likely be overturned.  But if the court rules narrowly - as it has liked to do recently, they will find the FWS acted per statute.  Has the appellant suffered damage?  Yes, yes he has.  Has he documented his damage.   No in the proceedings to date.  TLDR:  I think on the narrow ruling - did the secretaty erroneously apply the ESA, I think the answer is easily and clearly no.  On the broader question:  Hey, this is an unconstitutional taking, and its been established precedent for dozens of years.  How the hell do we deal with that?  Especially since in Sweet Home precedent was established and this would overturn. So.  I don't think the court will make any brave new precedent on a 4/4 court.  Usually on a tie, the judgement of the under court is affirmed.  Finally, under usual ED, the threshold seems to be about 20% infringement.  The appellant has suffered hundres of thousands of dollars in damages, but I don't think the record establishes that it makes the threshold requirement.  Even longer TLDR... Interesting case.  In principle, the ESA gives no reviewability for a decision not to exclude.   Yet, the plaintiffs comment that a decision not to exclude is tantamount to a decision to include - which is reviewable.  Secondly, I side with the FWS that the injury suffered by Weyerhauser is a phantom injury.  Thirdly, I think the FWS makes a good argument on the necessity of the land.  Were this only a question of these things, I would rate this 20% yes. However, this is the first opportunity to rule on Chevron - which the Supreme Court has been itching to rule on, and is presuably the reason it took the case up.  The only possibly issue here is the FWS's determination of what is critical habitat.  Overturning chevron would overturn deference to agency findings in favor of the law. So.  Since this is a vehicle for Chevron, I raise the chance to 51%, presuming a Kavanaugh or similar placement to the court.  Absent that ... odds remain at 20%.
